poem:
**Scrambled Egg Lichen**

Awake, a yellow scrabble upon earth's page,  
sunkissed fragments clinging to Breckland's fade.  
With bookbinding glue, we mend time's tear,  
scribe lichen back to Norfolk's airy lair.  
A history re-written in sunlit script,  
breath of bookworms, soil-bound and tight-knit.  
Once silent, now bright whispers in moss-spoken lore.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Rare lichen brought back to East Anglia with help of bookbinding glue A rare lichen has been reintroduced to its historical habitat of East Anglia – with the help of some bookbinding glue. Scrambled egg lichen, so named for its bright yellow, crumbly appearance, was once common in the Breckland region of Norfolk and Suffolk but was last seen there in 1994. It is thought to have become extinct due to habitat loss resulting from". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
